title: The Capture director hints Shaun Emery won't be returning
text:
Warning: Article contains spoilers for The Capture

Shaun Emery’s story is pretty much done and dusted in The Capture (Picture: BBC)

The Capture writer Ben Channan has hinted that Shaun Emery (Callum Turner) won’t be back if he made second series.

The finale of the first series saw Shaun turn himself in, and in Ben’s mind that means his story is all wrapped up.

Instead future episodes would focus on a new story for Holliday Grainger’s character DI Rachel Carey.

He told Radio Times: ‘I always wanted Shaun Emery’s story to be resolved within these six hours because I don’t like stringing people along.

‘I think people are watching partly – possibly mainly – every week to find out what happened to Shaun.

‘We want to know who’s done this to him, who really took Hannah, who faked the video, and why. And I hope we answer all those questions satisfyingly.’

He mysteriously added that ‘anything is possible’ but reiterated that there was nothing more to add to his story arc.

Shaun Emery’s tragic fate was inevitable in The Capture (Picture: BBC)

As for whether we will be getting a second series, Ben told Metro.co.uk that he couldn’t ‘confirm or deny’ anything, but talks are happening behind-the-scenes.

Channan went on to explain to us why Shaun’s fate was sealed from the get-go, but Rachel’s was a little more complicated.

‘I knew that’s how I was going to end it for Shaun,’ he said.

‘It had to be a sad ending. But there is a ray of hope – his ex is now talking to him, showing him pictures of her with the kid.

‘Shaun doesn’t care about other people; he cares about what his daughter thinks and his closest friends and relatives. He doesn’t want his daughter thinking he’s a murderer and he kidnapped her; Karen is going to make sure of that. So he gets that.

‘I knew the system had to win. Shaun and Carey can’t bring the system down – the system always wins.’

The Capture is available on BBC iPlayer.
